We cannot conceive of a personality who is simultaneously unborn and still takes birth. He is active, yet he has nothing to do. So we cannot conceive what kind of a personality is that. We have to hear devotees like Venkati. Now, there is a description of Krishna's Viratrupa or Vishwarupa, one form of the Lord. The external body of Krishna as described in the description given of the Viratrupa or Vishwarupa. The hills and mountains are described as the bones of the Lord. So many hills are there. So many mountains are there. They are all described as the bones of the Virat Purusha. The great oceans have been described as the different holes in the Lord's universal body. The planet Brahmaloka has been described as the upper portion of his skull. Like this, the universal form has been described in so many ways. But then, the earth and the sky are intended to be the upper portion, because they are the set of the earth. The certain part of the earth and the sky is where the earth is. This is the only thing about which the universe is. Let us veer from the present state. In Brahma's view, the matter of the universe is to have run—what makes the universe and God's existence both greater than the matter of the universe. Now, it is said here, Brahma Shankar Prabhupada, there are people who can simply think of God as being great, but they do not know how great he is. So, therefore, the Vishwaroopa description of the Lord, Supreme Lord is given in the scriptures that if you think of greatness of the Supreme Lord, think of the hills and mountains as the bones of the universal form. Arjuna was given special eyes to see that universal form. Otherwise, nobody can see this form of the Supreme Lord. So, Krishna is simultaneously greater than the greatest, Mahato Mahiyan, and he is smaller than the smallest, Anoranyan. That is Krishna's wonderful characteristic. Simultaneously, he is greater than the greatest and smaller than the smallest. So, the Vishwaroopa is the biggest form of anyone in this entire universe, and the form of the Supersoul who has entered into every atom is much, much smaller than the atom. That form of the Lord is actually the Lord being smaller than the smallest, Anoranyan. So, this is also greatness of the Lord. Simultaneously, he is present as greater than the greatest and smaller than the smallest.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xrt90oUh-bA?t=628
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Transmigration means, I am leaving one body and entering another body."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the concept of transmigration, where the soul leaves one body and enters another, emphasizing that death is not the end of existence but a migration to a new body.

Therefore, a person becomes entangled in the chain of birth and death by transmigrating into different bodies. You should understand this word, transmigration. Transmigration means I am leaving one body and entering another body, while I am not aware that I have changed my body. I am existing through the changes, but I am not aware of that. That's why it's called transmigration. Migration, you understand. Just say, a person migrates from India to America. He leaves India and he goes to America, say, migrated to America. Actually, a similar thing happens when we die. Death is not the end of our existence. Death means we migrate from this body to another body, new body. But because that change happens without our knowledge, without our understanding, it's called transmigration. And actually life is continuous through the changes of the body.

#### transmigration, illusion, threefold miseries, material life
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xrt90oUh-bA?t=724
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In that next body, a person thinks, I have come into existence when I was born, which is a mistake, which is an incorrect understanding."
**Summary:** The lecture continues on transmigration, highlighting the illusion of forgetting past lives and the incorrect understanding of coming into existence at birth, and emphasizing that threefold miseries persist even when changing bodies.

Just like we change body from childhood to youth to old age. Do we think that we are different person from childhood to youth when the change happens? No. I am quite aware. I am the same person. I had the body of a child. Now I have the body of a young man when I become youthful, when I go to the youthful stage. So, I don't think that I am a different person. But what happens when we quit this body at the time of death and enter another body? Mostly, in most cases, a person forgets about the previous life. That is one thing. Second thing, in that next body, a person thinks, "I have come into existence when I was born," which is a mistake, which is an incorrect understanding. So, in the chain of birth and death, by transmigrating to different bodies on different planets, this happens under the direction of the Supreme Lord. He is completely in control, the Supreme Lord. So, Srila Prabhupada explains, unless one is beyond the boundary of this nescience or ignorance or misunderstanding, misconception, one cannot get free from the threefold miseries of material life. One cannot get free. The threefold miseries will be there in material existence, even if we change bodies. Miseries are not going to vanish.

#### repetition of birth and death, transcendental activities, Krishna's lotus feet
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/w2np8N3hAs4?t=54
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "O Krishna, those who continuously hear, chant and repeat your transcendental activities or take pleasure in others doing so certainly see your lotus feet which alone can stop the repetition of birth and death."
**Summary:** Kunti Devi explains how hearing, chanting, and repeating Krishna's transcendental activities, or even taking pleasure in others doing so, can lead to liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

In this session we will be discussing from the 36th verse of the 8th chapter of the 1st canto of Shreemad Bhagavatam, continuing the prayers by Queen Kunti. श्रिन्वन्ति गायन्ति गृणन्ति भीक्ष्णशः स्मरन्ति नन्दन्ति तवेहितं जनाह तैयेवपश्यंति अचिरेणतावकं भवप्रवाहो परमं पदाम्बुजम. The meaning of this verse is, O Krishna, those who continuously hear, chant, and repeat your transcendental activities or take pleasure in others doing so, certainly see your lotus feet which alone can stop the repetition of birth and death. So Kunti Devi is explaining how one can end this repetition of birth and death. Of course, most people do not know that the real fundamental problem of material existence is this repetition of birth and death. It's called samsara or bhava. So this accepting this material body, while we are actually not got anything to do with matter, we are pure spirit and we have our spiritual body, we have our spiritual heart, we have our home, the abode of Krishna, Krishnaloka, but foolishly we give up that spiritual home and we desire independent enjoyment, we desire to lord over material nature and therefore we are forced to take this material body which is called birth and we cannot remain in this material body permanently, we have to quit this material body by force, that's called death and after death if we still have desire for lording over or we have desire for material enjoyment, independent enjoyment then we have to continue to accept another body and that's another birth. So jatasyahi dhruva mṛtyu dhruvam janma mṛtasyaca Krishna explains this in the Bhagavad Gita, for one who has taken his birth in this material world death is certain and after death if one is not liberated at the time of death then one has to take birth again, cannot avoid. So Kunti Devi is now telling who can actually stop this repetition of birth and death, those who continuously hear, chant, and repeat the transcendental activities of Krishna or even if they don't do it they simply take pleasure in somebody else who is doing that, such persons are able to have darshan of Krishna's lotus feet by which they are very easily able to conquer this material existence, they are able to stop the repetition of birth and death.

Today, though we are completely dependent on your mercy and have no one else to protect us, now when all kings are at enmity with us. This verse, spoken by Kunti Devi in a prayer to Krishna, is clearly indicating the position of a pure devotee like Kunti Devi on the Supreme Lord Krishna. In a sense, what is Kunti Devi telling? My dear Lord Krishna, we are dependent on you. We are totally dependent on your mercy. We have no one else for protecting us. Only you are our protector. This is the factual position of everyone, not only Kunti Devi, but pure devotees know this, recognize this, and always take shelter of Krishna. The non-devotees, they try to take shelter of so many other so-called shelters, but they are not. But nobody else can protect us, the living beings, except Krishna.

It was Krishna's plan that the Pandavas should actually be ruling the entire world because they are the proper representatives of Krishna, the Supreme Lord, being pure devotees of Krishna. Only a pure devotee can properly rule this world and actually guide the people to become Krishna conscious, to get out of this material entanglement. That's the whole plan of the Supreme Lord in this material world.

#### Purpose of material creation, Conditioned souls, Liberation, Role of a Kshatriya king
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/lwNrAcADhF4?t=320

Sometimes people wonder, what is the purpose of this creation? The purpose of this creation is to give a chance to the conditioned souls. All of us are called conditioned souls. We are conditioned by this material nature. We develop desires to enjoy, thinking that we are this body, we belong to this world. And our life continues birth after birth after birth because we have so many varieties of desires for enjoying. But actually Krishna's purpose is different. Krishna wants us to realize we don't belong here because we are spirit, soul, we are not the body. And as spiritual beings, we can never be really satisfied and happy by material pleasures, by material enjoyment, by material lordship. We can never be satisfied or happy. So Krishna wants us to realize this. And for this purpose, Krishna has created this world in such a way that in the human form of life, we have developed intelligence. And if we are guided on the spiritual path of emancipation, of liberation from material bondage, then very easily we are able to understand and act appropriately under proper guidance and become completely free from all entanglements and go back to our original position in the spiritual world to enjoy eternal life of bliss and knowledge. This is the whole plan of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. This is the purpose of creation: to liberate all the living beings, especially the human beings. And a proper Kshatriya ruling the human beings, ruling this world and particularly guiding the human beings on this path of liberation. It is possible that everyone can be liberated if they are guided by a king like Yudhishthira.

**Summary:** The speaker discusses the apparent contradiction of a king's duty to kill miscreants versus Yudhishthira's feeling of guilt, highlighting Yudhishthira's humility and a pure devotee's sensitivity to the consequences of their actions.

The meaning is, there is no sin for a king who kills for the right cause, who is engaged in maintaining his citizens, but this injunction is not applicable to me. A king has to engage in violence when there is a necessity of protecting innocent creatures, of protecting the weaker sections of society, of protecting women, of protecting saintly persons, of protecting brahmanas. Then he has to actually kill the miscreants. That's the duty of the king. But Yudhishthira Maharaj is thinking that even though a king has got a duty to kill the miscreants, but this killing in this battle is not applicable, is not proper for King Yudhishthira. This is Yudhishthira Maharaj's thinking. Before performing the action there is so much of thinking, there is so much of precautions taken.

In the fourth chapter of Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says, chaaturvarnyam maya-srishtam guna-karma-vibhaga-saha. He says, it is I who have created these four divisions of social orders in human society: chaaturvarnyam brahmana-kshatriya-vaisa-shudra. Society can be perfectly organised in that way: the intellectuals, the administrators, the business class, the productive class, that is the business class, and the labourers. And different people have different skills, different qualities. They are born under different influences of the gunas. Accordingly, they can be engaged properly in some livelihood, means of livelihood. But everybody is entitled, eligible for ultimate liberation in the human form of life. And that's what the whole varnashrama dharma is about: how to worship Vishnu by performance of your duty in such a way that you will actually be ultimately liberated from material bondage.

Right now, what is our condition? We are under the clutches of the illusory energy and therefore our life in this body is temporary. We are on the material platform of the three gunas in which there is creation, maintenance, and destruction. The characteristic of Raja Guna is creation. The characteristic of Sattva Guna is maintenance. The characteristic of Dhamma Guna is destruction. So this body is created and that is when we say birth takes place and then this body is maintained when we say there is sustenance of this body the body is maintained and then at a certain time after a limited duration of time this body will be destroyed. This body cannot be maintained anymore. We say death. Death means the destruction of the body. So it is totally different on the spiritual platform. We as each one of us is spirit soul. It is totally different. A living entity is so made by the will of the Almighty that he is most happy when placing himself in a condition of absolute dependence. See the nature of spiritual life is such that there is absolute dependence on Krishna. And material life means there is relativity. Somebody I can depend more somebody I cannot depend as much somebody else may be somewhat dependable all these relativities exist but there is no one I can absolutely depend on because nobody is fully secure themselves. Their own position is always shaky. In terms of their material body anyone who is in a position of security anyone who possesses a material body because of taking birth under the illusory energy their own position is insecure. So what security they can give to others when their own position is not secure. The opposite tendency is the cause of fall down.

#### Unflinching devotion, Krishna's protection, relationship of the soul, Bhishma's example
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/H5XIV92y_1M?t=790
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The appearance of Lord Krishna at the deathbed of Bhishma ji is due to his being an unflinching devotee of the Lord."
**Summary:** The speaker reiterates that Krishna's appearance at Bhishma's deathbed is due to his unflinching devotion and emphasizes that the relationship between the soul and the Supreme Soul is eternal and not based on bodily connections.

The appearance of Lord Krishna at the deathbed of Bhishma ji is due to his being an unflinching devotee of the Lord. So when somebody is a pure devotee under all circumstances, unfailing in all circumstances, then the Supreme Lord protects such a devotee always, especially when the devotee has to quit the body at the time of death. That is a critical moment in one's life. Arjuna had some bodily relation with Krishna because the Lord happened to be his maternal cousin. But he did not have any physical relation with Krishna. But Bhishma had no such bodily relation. When Krishna helps the Pandavas, somebody may think that, Oh, because Krishna is related to the Pandavas through some bodily relationship. Actually, there is no bodily relationship between Krishna and anybody. Krishna does not have a material body. So where is the question of bodily relationship? But even if for the sake of his Leela, he appears as the son of Devaki or Vasudeva. Vasudeva and Kunti are having that blood relationship. Vasudeva is the brother of Kunti. So Kunti's sons, the Pandavas, and Vasudeva's son Krishna, through such relationships between Vasudeva and Kunti, they are related as maternal cousins. But what about Bhishma? Bhishma has no such bodily relationship. So therefore, Prabhupada says, in the case of Bhishma, the cause of attraction was due to the intimate relation of the soul. So how is it that Krishna appeared in front of Bhishma? And Bhishma is acknowledging that very kindly the Supreme Lord has appeared when I am about to quit the body. It is because of the relationship of the soul. And that relation is eternal. It is never based on any bodily connections. It is a relationship between the soul with the Supreme Soul.

So also it is stated in the Skanda Purana, this confirmed in the Skanda Purana also, spiritual form cannot be destroyed by any weapon. It is said there that spirit is always uncontaminated and indestructible. Spirit is never contaminated by matter. Even in our case, even though there is a material covering for our original spiritual form, still that spiritual form or spirit cannot be contaminated by matter. This remains like a superficial covering only and it cannot be destroyed. Spiritual form cannot be destroyed, it is eternal form. It cannot be distressed nor it can be dried up, it cannot be distressed the spiritual form.

Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Jai Vanarottamam Devim Sarasvatim Vyasam Tato Jaya Mudhirayet. In this session, we will be discussing from the 40th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Lalitha Gati Vilasa Valguhasa Pranaya Niriksana Kalpitoru Manaha Krita Manu Krita Vatya Unma Dandhaha Prakritim Agan Kilayasya Gopa Vadhvaha. The meaning of this verse is, let my mind be fixed upon Lord Sri Krishna, whose motions and smiles of love attracted the damsels of Raja Dharma, the Gopis. The damsels imitated the characteristic movements of the Lord after his disappearance from the Rasa dance. This is yet another precept. This is the same prayer offered by Bhishma Deva to Lord Krishna. Bhishma is fixing his mind upon Lord Sri Krishna and remembering the different pastimes of Krishna. Smaranam, remembering the pastimes of Krishna, remembering the form of Krishna, remembering the name of Krishna, remembering the qualities of Krishna. This is bhakti. This is the practice of bhakti. Here, specifically, Bhishma Deva is remembering Krishna's pastimes with his topmost devotees, the Gopis of Vrindavan. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains what is the characteristic of the Gopis' devotion to Krishna. It is explained by Srila Prabhupada in the purport, By intense ecstasy in loving service, the damsels of Vraja Bhumi, that is the Gopis, attained qualitative oneness with the Lord by dancing with him on an equal level, by embracing him in nuptial love, by smiling at him, by looking at him in joke, and by looking at him with a loving attitude. The Gopis are in a relationship with Krishna in conjugal love. Conjugal love means love between opposite genders. Actually, Krishna is the only male, and everyone else is female. Krishna is the only Purusha, everyone else is Prakriti. So, this love between Krishna and the devotees is natural, is our constitutional position. So, among the devotees of Krishna, the topmost devotees are the Gopis. Now, Srila Prabhupada says, the relation of the Lord with Arjuna is undoubtedly praiseworthy for devotees like Bhishma Deva, because Arjuna's friendship with the Lord was very, very intimate friendship. It was transcendental relationship, not material friendship. But, the relation of the Gopis with the Lord is still more praiseworthy because of their still more purified loving service. Now, how is Gopis' devotional service more purified? To understand that, Srila Prabhupada explains, that according to Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, ramyakachit upasana vrajavadhu vargena yakalpita. The meaning of this is, this is what Chaitanya Mahaprabhu says about the Gopis' devotional service rendered to Lord Krishna. There is no better method of worship than the system invented by the Gopis. Worship of Krishna. The best method of worship is that which was performed by the Gopis of Vrindavan. So, the Gopis' invention of worshipping Krishna was to remain always Krishna conscious without any material profit. That is the super excellence of the Gopis. Super excellent devotional service. They never expected any return from Krishna. That was not their business. Their attitude was not like, Krishna, we have done so much for you. Can you give us some benediction, Krishna? So it is explained by Sri Lakshmi that after gaining victory in the battle of Kurukshetra, Maharaj Yudhishthira, the emperor of the world, performed a Rajasuya sacrificial ceremony. The emperor in those days, upon his ascendance to the throne, would send a challenge horse all over the world to declare his supremacy, and any ruling prince or king was at liberty to accept the challenge and express his tacit willingness either to obey or to disobey the supremacy of the particular king of the world. The world was ruled in different provinces by different kings, but one king was the emperor of the whole world. Generally, the king whose capital was Hastinapura, at least 5000 years back, that was the system. So one who accepted the challenge of the emperor, whichever king, king of a smaller province, he had to fight with the emperor and establish his own supremacy by victory. The defeated challenger would have to sacrifice his life, making a place for another king or ruler. This was the system. So Maharaj Yudhishthira also dispatched such challenging horses all over the world, and every ruling prince and king all over the world accepted Maharaj Yudhishthira's leadership as the emperor of the world.

In this session we will be discussing from the 46th verse of the 9th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. तस्य निर्हरणादीनि संपरे तस्य भार्गव युदिष्ठिरक कारयित्वा मुहूर्तं दुख्यितो भवत। The meaning of this verse is, O descendant of Bhrigu, शवनका, after performing funeral rituals for the dead body of Bhishma Deva, Maharaj Yudhishthira was momentarily overtaken with grief. So, Suta Goswami speaking this verse, he is addressing Shavunaka Rishi, the sages headed by Shavunaka Rishi. Shavunaka Rishi is addressed as Bhargava, descendant of Bhrigu Rishi or Bhrigu Muni. He is coming in the dynasty of Bhrigu Rishi, Bhrigu Vamsha. So, the description is being given here that Yudhishthira, after Bhishma Deva passed away, he quit his body at the most auspicious moment, and more importantly, he quit his body in the presence of Lord Sri Krishna, and he quit his body while his mind was completely absorbed in thought, in remembrance of Krishna. So, perfect way of quitting the body, ideal for all the devotees, for everyone. So, in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, Bhishma Deva was not only a great family head of Maharaj Yudhishthira, but also he was a great philosopher and friend to him, his brothers and his mother, the entire Pandavas. Kunti is the name of a family, the five Pandavas brothers, and their mother Kunti, Kunti Devi. Since Maharaj Pandu, the father of the five brothers headed by Maharaj Yudhishthira, had died, Bhishma Deva was the most affectionate grandfather of the Pandavas, and caretaker of the widow daughter-in-law Kunti Devi. Bhishma Deva's granddaughter was the daughter of Lord Pundit, Krishna's daughter, Bhishmadeva's brother was Vichitravirya. Vichitravirya's son was Pandu. So, Bhishmadeva's daughter-in-law or Vichitravirya's daughter-in-law was Kuntidevi. In that way, it is being described here, Bhishmadeva's relationship with Kuntidevi. Although Maharaj Dhritarashtra, the elder uncle of Maharaj Yudhishthira, was there to look after them, his affection, that is Dhritarashtra's affection, was more on the side of his hundred sons, headed by Duryodhana. Dhritarashtra was very much unhappy about the fact that Dhritarashtra himself could not ascend the throne of the emperor of the entire world, the throne of Hastinapura, because Dhritarashtra was blind by birth. He was disqualified. And Pandu had taken charge of ruling the entire world as the emperor, and Pandu died. And Yudhishthira should have ascended the throne, but if Dhritarashtra is not dead, would that mean he shall not be a successor? Since Yudhishthira was not an adult, a major—he was not quite eighteen years old—therefore, after Pandu died, as long as Yudhishthira would yield to the throne, a caretaker king was needed. And that caretaker king Bhishma refused because Bhishma had taken a vow not to sit on the throne. He had given a promise to his father. Therefore Dhritarashtra was the caretaker king and Bhishma and Vidura were advising.

So Prabhupada explains all the Vedic hymns are chanted to please Lord Krishna. All the Vedas, this is confirmed in the Bhagavad Gita in the 15th chapter, 15 verse. Krishna says, vedais ca sarvair aham eva vedyo. What is the meaning of this? All the Vedic literature is meant for understanding me. Who is telling this? Krishna. So all the Vedic literature is meant for understanding Krishna, knowing Krishna, and Prabhupada also says all the Vedas, Upanishads, Vedanta are seeking Krishna only, and all Vedas and all hymns, Vedic hymns are for glorifying Krishna only.

So, this Atheist Kapila analyzes matter as consisting of 24 elements. What are the 24 elements? First of all, this is described in the Bhagavad Gita by Krishna himself in the 13th chapter. In the 7th chapter and 13th chapter, Krishna describes, in the 13th chapter particularly, Mahabhutani ahankara buddhir avyakta mevaca. That Mahabhutani, the five great elements, earth, water, fire, air and sky. These are called the five great elements. And then there are the ten senses. The five knowledge, the five knowledge acquiring senses, Gyanendriya: the eyes, the ears, the nose, the tongue and the sense of touch. Then the five karmendriyas or the five working senses: the hands, the legs, the voice, the anus and the genitals. So, totally that makes it 15. And then five more senses, the sense objects. For the eyes, there are form. And for the ears, there is sound. For the nose, there is smell, different kinds of fragrances or different kinds of smells. And then for the tongue, there are different kinds of tastes. And for the sense of touch, there are different kinds of feelings of softness, hardness, whatever the kind of sensation of touch. So, these five sense objects called indriya visaya. Totally, five fours are 20. And then four more for making it 24 total elements, which is what matter is constituted of: mind, intelligence, and false ego. Mind is manas, buddhi, intelligence, ahankara, false ego. And finally, there is the total stock of the unmanifested material energy, avyakta. Avyakta is the total stock of the material energy from which these elements are differentiated at the beginning of creation.

#### inconceivable energies of the Lord, devotee's perspective, karma, illusory energy (Maya)
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/xsLpu-f0ZTY?t=51
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The material energy is always provoking doubts about the supreme authority of the Lord."
**Summary:** This segment discusses the inconceivable nature of the Lord's energies, the role of Maya, and how a devotee should not blame others or the Lord for difficulties, understanding the chain of cause and effect and the influence of past karma.

In this session we will be discussing from the 23rd verse of the 17th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. अथवा देवामायाया नूनम गतिर अगोचरा चेतसो वचसस्चापी भूतानाम इति निष्चयहा The meaning of this 23rd verse is, "Thus it is concluded that the Lord's energies are inconceivable. No one can estimate them by mental speculation or by word." Now, this is a conclusion that is drawn by Pariksit Maharaj. The Lord's energies are inconceivable. The Lord's energies are working, especially in this material world and even in the spiritual world. But in the spiritual world it is the spiritual energy, internal potency which is working. And in the material world it is the external potency, the material energy which is working. Both of them are controlled, owned, directed by the Supreme Lord only. Krishna only is the owner, controller, director, master of all the energies. So, by mental speculation we cannot figure out how the Lord's energies are working. How the Lord's energies are working in different circumstances. We cannot make calculation, material calculation. That's impossible. So, in the Purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, "A question may be raised as to why a devotee should refrain from identifying an actor, although he knows definitely that the Lord is the ultimate doer of everything. A devotee does not blame anyone for any difficulty or danger." A doer knows the problem he may be facing. Why? Even though he knows that the Lord is the ultimate doer. But that doesn't mean he blames the Lord. Neither he blames the person who is the immediate cause. And therefore he also blames the Lord as the person who is the immediate cause, because there are a chain of causes and defects. And every effect there is a cause, and every cause there is a particular justification why, why that cause is actually being sanctioned by the law. Knowing the ultimate doer, one should not pose himself as ignorant of the actual performer. So, it's not that because anyway, ultimately, every person suffers because of his or her own past bad karma, I or anyone else doesn't have the license to inflict harm on others, that is not a license. It's just like sometimes people say, anyway, the animal is going to die. So, if I kill it for some food, what is wrong there? It's going to die. Animal is not the body. After all, I can only kill the body. I cannot kill the soul. Animal or the living entity is the soul. So, this reasoning or argument is not correct, is invalid. The perpetrator of a sinful activity is definitely responsible for this sinful action, and is going to be punished by God's laws, the laws of karma. Of this, there is no doubt at all. Yet, when the sinful action is sanctioned by the Lord, then there is a higher cause. So, it is said here, to answer this doubt, the reply is that the Lord is also not directly responsible for everything, is done by his deputed maya shakti or material energy. In the material world, maya shakti, material energy is working. In every case, every material action, material energy is working. The material energy is always provoking doubts about the supreme authority of the Lord, because we directly don't see the Lord's hand in every action in this material world. But still, the fact is, the Lord is always in the background, and he only is directing the material energy. The personality of religion knew perfectly well that nothing can take place without the sanction of the Supreme Lord, and still he was put into doubts by the deluding energy. And thus, he refrained from mentioning the supreme cause. This doubtfulness was due to the contamination of both Kali and the material energy. When dharma does not complain against the Kali Purusha, so, does it mean that, oh, Kali Purusha is not directly responsible, so, he is not a culprit. So, Pariksit need not punish him? No, that is incorrect. At the same time, the Lord is sanctioning, only then Kali Purusha can do some harm. So, Lord is responsible? No, the Lord is not responsible. The whole atmosphere of the age of Kali is magnified by the deluding energy, and the proportion of measurement is inexplicable. The material world always, Maya's actions are definitely the direct cause of any suffering that anybody may undergo. But then, our own past sinful actions are also responsible. We are responsible. So, how does this illusory energy work? Is the question that may be raised. So, it is not easy to understand the working of the illusory energy in each and every case.

So, I want to briefly narrate a particular description in the 12th Kant of the Bhagavatam. Tiruvannamalai. There was one Markandeya Rishi. But he is seeing the illusory energy working. So many people are under the clutches of maya and they are engaged in either material enjoyment or they sometimes suffer and they are in ignorance and they are perpetually in the cycle of birth and death. They have no clue how to get out because of ignorance. So how is this material energy working? I wanted to see. This is what Markandeya wanted to actually ask the Lord. So once when Markandeya Rishi was sitting in his ashram performing his spiritual practice, the Supreme Lord appeared in his incarnation as Naranarayanarishi, the twin sages. And Markandeya Rishi received Naranarayanarishi very nicely. And after they had been offered all kinds of good reception, according to Vedic culture, then when they were seated, Markandeya Rishi offered nice prayers to them and the Lord, being satisfied, asked him, "You can ask any benediction that you desire." So he said, "I am not interested in any material benefit," knowing very well that they are useless from a spiritual perspective. "But I want to... I wish to see your illusory potency, by whose influence the entire world, together with its ruling demigods, consider reality to be materially variegated." They mistake this material energy itself to be the absolute truth. No. Material energy is not the absolute truth. Krishna is the absolute truth. Krishna is in the background. And they departed for their ashram in Badrikashram. Thinking always of his desire to see the Lord's illusory energy, Markandeya Rishi remained in his ashram, meditating constantly upon the Lord within fire, the sun, the moon, the water, the earth, the air, lightning, his own heart, and worshipping him with paraphernalia conceived in his mind.

One day, while Markandeya Rishi was performing his evening worship, suddenly a great wind arose. That wind created a terrible sound and brought in its wake fearsome clouds that were accompanied by lightning and roaring thunder. And the clouds poured down torrents of rain. Then on all sides, Markandeya Rishi saw the four great oceans swelling up. And there was gusty wind. And these oceans were filled with sea monsters. And they were very, very fearsome. There were whirlpools. The sage saw all the inhabitants of the universe, including himself, tormented by the harsh winds. The bolts of lightning, the great waves rising beyond the sky, the whole earth became flooded, and he became perplexed and fearful. Remember, Markandeya Rishi had prayed to the Lord, "I want to see your illusory energy in action." And now, actually the Lord is showing him what is my illusory energy like. Even as Markandeya looked on, the rain pouring down from the clouds filled the ocean more and more and more until the great sea covered up the earth's islands, mountains, continents. Completely the earth became submerged. Not only that water flooded the earth, but it also flooded the outer space, heaven, celestial region. Entire expanse of the universe was flooded in all directions. And it appeared like only Markandeya Rishi remained alive in that flood, great deluge, devastating flood. His matted hair scattered. The great sage wandered about alone in the water as if dumb and blind. He didn't know where to go, what to do. He's alive. He's somehow floating. And he doesn't know where to go and what to do. He was also tormented by hunger and thirst. He was attacked by monstrous makaras and timingala fish. Makaras means crocodiles. And very dangerous crocodiles which are huge. You can easily swallow up hundreds of Markandeya Rishis. And timingala fish. These fishes are very, very dangerous. They can devour an entire big blue sea whale. Huge. As big as ocean liners. That is attacked by a timingala. Timingala is very, very dangerous. So he saw timingala fishes. He saw monstrous crocodiles. And he was battered by the wind and waves. He moved aimlessly in the infinite darkness into which he had fallen. Suddenly, he saw millions of years pass like that, wandering in that huge flood. His mind bewildered by the illusory energy of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Lord Vishnu.

#### illusory energy (Maya), Markandeya Rishi, vata patra shayi, divine revelation, liberation

Once while wandering in the water, millions of years have passed, this Brahmana Markandeya Rishi discovered a small island. Now on this small island was a young banyan tree. And it was having... It was unaffected by that flood, by the hurricane wind, by the violent storm, everything. This stood with nice fruits and nice blossoms of flowers. Now on a branch of that tree, he saw an infant boy, small boy, lying within a leaf. The child's effulgence was swallowing up the darkness. The infant's dark blue complexion was the color of a flawless emerald. His lotus face shone with a wealth of beauty. His throat bore marks like the lines of a conch shell. This is the Supreme Lord appearing in that form, Vata Patra Shai. He is lying on a banyan leaf, and he was sucking the toe within his mouth. So Markandeya when he saw the child, all his fatigue vanished. And just looking at the child, he felt great joy within his heart. Now who is this infant? He tried to go near the infant. And suddenly the child inhaled everything, and Markandeya found himself within the body of the child. And inside he found the universe was as it was before the dissolution. He was astonished. He saw the heavens. He saw the earth. He saw the stars. He saw the mountains. He saw everything. And he saw before him his own Badra river, his own hermitage. Now as he was kind of thinking, oh now the illusion is over, suddenly the infant exhaled and expelled the sage out of its abdomen. And he was back into the ocean of dissolution. At that moment that child, when he came out, became again visible, invisible, became invisible. And suddenly everything vanished. The whole storm and the oceans which were flooded, everything vanished. And Markandeya Rishi found himself in his ashram, as he was seated. So this was the display of the illusory energy by the Lord. I'll stop here. Thank you very much.

#### Devotion to Rama, Testing of Faith, Steadfastness, Unwavering Faith, Incarnation of Hanuman
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/hoeoWS0w8sI?t=119
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Although Murari heard these divine glories of Krishna from the Lord himself, his heart remained steadfastly fixed on his eternal master Lord Ramachandra."
**Summary:** The story of Lord Chaitanya testing Murari Gupta's devotion to Lord Rama and recognizing him as an incarnation of Hanuman.

When Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu one day appeared in ecstasy as the Varaha Murti, Murari Gupta offered him nice prayers. Murari Gupta gave Zuvar posso kepada Sat-Siat Rao one time. Once Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu glorified Murari Gupta for his unflinching devotion and loyalty to Lord Rama Chandra because Murari Gupta was a great devotee of Lord Rama. In Mahaprakasha form, Lord Chaitanya appeared before Murari Gupta as Lord Ramachandra. Just to test Murari's faith, he repeatedly encouraged Murari Gupta to shift his worship from Lord Rama to Lord Krishna, describing the unparalleled sweetness, supremacy, and all-attractive nature of Shri Krishna, who is the origin of all incarnations and the reservoir of all transcendental qualities and pleasure. Although Murari heard these divine glories of Krishna from the Lord himself, his heart remained steadfastly fixed on his eternal master Lord Ramachandra. Murari, being utterly devoted, could not imagine giving up the service of Lord Rama's lotus feet. That night he was deeply troubled, weeping continuously and praying that death might take him before he was forced to abandon his worship of Lord Ramachandra. He spent the entire night awake, overwhelmed by distress. The next morning Murari approached Lord Chaitanya, fell at his feet, and humbly confessed that though he desired to please the Lord, he could not forsake Lord Ramachandra, for he had sold his head and heart to Lord Rama's service. Torn between obedience to Chaitanya's command and loyalty to Lord Ramachandra, Murari begged for death as his only release. Hearing this pure devotion, Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu became overjoyed. Embracing Murari Gupta, Lord Chaitanya praised his unwavering faith, declaring that such steadfast devotion is a true hallmark of a servant. The Lord revealed that his repeated persuasion was merely a test to demonstrate Murari's deep, unbreakable attachment to Lord Ramachandra.

#### childhood, devotion, detachment
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Ugj5n_4y1b8?t=47
**Verse References:** —

**Summary:** Description of Narottam Das Thakur's birth, childhood, early signs of devotion, and growing detachment from material life.

in the village of Kheturi in present-day Bangladesh around the mid-16th century. Narottama appeared on the full moon day of Magha as the son of King Krishnananda Datta and Queen Narayani Devi. His birth was marked by auspicious omens, and the entire kingdom rejoiced with his father distributing generous charity to the local brahmanas. Even as a child, Narottama demonstrated profound devotion during his Annaprashana ceremony, which is the first grain feeding ceremony for the infant child. He refused to eat until the food was first offered to Lord Krishna, thus teaching the sanctity of Prasadam. An astrologer observing his divine features declared that the child would become the greatest among men and thus should be named Narottama. Gifted with an extraordinary memory, Narottama was a Shruti Dharam, able to retain everything he heard. He mastered Sanskrit, grammar and the Vedas with ease, but his heart was fixed on serving Krishna. Remaining a lifelong Brahmachari, he was indifferent to the comforts of royal life. Concerned by his growing detachment, his parents placed guards to keep watch over him. But Narottama's only happiness lay in hearing the divine pastimes of Lord Chaitanya and Lord Nityananda, narrated to him daily.

daily by Shri Krishnadas Kaviraj Goswami. Immersed in remembrance of the Lord, he once had a dream in which Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu instructed him to travel to Vrindavan. When his father was away, Narottama escaped from home to fulfill the Lord's instruction. As he journeyed toward Vrindavan, his saintly nature attracted everyone's affection and people offered him food and shelter along the way. Upon reaching Vrindavan, he met Srila Jeeva Goswami and Srinivasa Acharya. Their meeting was filled with spiritual joy and affection and Narottama and Srinivasa soon became inseparable friends united in their love for the Lord. Srila Jeeva Goswami introduced Narottama to Shri Loknath Goswami. Narottama humbly fell at his feet and Loknath Goswami moved by his sincerity blessed him and later agreed to initiate him. Srila Jeeva Goswami also introduced Narottama to Shri Gopalabhatta Goswami and Shri Bhuggadbhag Goswami who received him affectionately. Narottama visited the holy temples of Rathadamoda and Madan Mohan and upon seeing the samadhis of Rupa and Sanatana Goswamis, he wept uncontrollably in love and devotion. Later with Srinivasa Acharya, he visited Radhakunda and Shamakunda and received the blessings of Sri Raghunath Das Goswami who was deeply touched by his devotion. Under the care of Jeeva Goswami, Narottama studied deeply the scriptures of Bhakti and soon became renowned for his humility, scholarship and realization. Srila Lokarnath Goswami, seeing Narottama's pure-hearted service finally initiated him into the chanting of the Maha Mantra. His exceptional understanding of devotional literature impressed all the Vaishnavas of Vrindavan and Sri Jeeva Goswami bestowed upon him the title Sri Thakur Mahasaya.

festival at his birthplace, the first large-scale God Purnima celebration which commemorates Lord Chaitanya's appearance. This event united Lord Chaitanya's followers from many regions and established the foundation for his worship across Bengal. Although born into a Kayastha community, traditionally considered of lower caste, Narottama became the spiritual master of thousands including many learned brahmanas such as Ganga Narayan Chakravarthi and Ramachandra Kaviraj. These exalted disciples humbly served him, acknowledging his transcendental position. Despite criticism from caste conscious brahmanas, Narottama remained compassionate, embracing everyone equally and demonstrating that spiritual qualification is measured by devotion not by birth. In his later life, Narottama became a spiritual master of the old caste. This is the reason why he became a spiritual master of the new caste. After his death, Narottama experienced deep separation from the Lord and his associates. Having witnessed the departure of the six Goswamis, Srinivas Acharya and Ramachandra Kaviraj, he poured his heart out in the famous song Jai Anilo Prema Dhana, expressing grief over the loss of the great devotees who brought divine love to the world. His disappearance was miraculous. Aware that bathe him by pouring Ganga water over his body. As they did this, his body turned white like milk and gradually melted into the sacred Ganges. Heartbroken but obedient, his disciples collected the mixture of milk, tears, and Ganga water and enshrined it at Kheturi, where a beautiful Samadhi was built, known as Dut Samadhi, the Samadhi of Milk. Srila Narottam Das Thakur remains a radiant example of pure devotion, humility, and compassion. His life and songs reveal the heart of Prema Bhakti, unconditional love for Krishna, and his teachings transcend all material distinctions. Srila Prabhupada revered his bhajans as spiritual scripture and they continue to inspire generations

**Summary:** The speaker describes the process of material creation, starting with Maha Vishnu entering the dormant material energy and leading to the birth of Brahma from Garbhodaka Shaini Vishnu.

In the third canto, when Lord Brahma offers His praise to Vishnu, did He offer the prayers before the material creation or after the creation? Now the material creation it's a long process. It begins with the Supreme Lord incarnating in this material world, in the material energy. The Lord enters as the first Vishnu form from the spiritual world who descends into this material energy. So that is called Karanodaka Shaini Vishnu, also called Maha Vishnu. So Maha Vishnu first appears, enters the material energy which is lying in a dormant condition, unmanifest condition. That means at that time there are no universes. Previous destruction took place and there was only the material energy. So that energy first of all Maha Vishnu enters. Then Maha Vishnu agitates that energy and the energy becomes activated by Maha Vishnu's glance. And then after Maha Vishnu's glance, first of all the agitation produces Mahatatva. And Mahatatva differentiates the elements. And those elements are combined to form varieties of material objects, material planets. And then from there is one expansion of this Maha Vishnu called Padmanabha Vishnu or Garbhodaka Shaini Vishnu. So that Garbhodaka Shaini Vishnu from his navel one lotus flower is born. On that Brahma is created by Vishnu.

Then Brahma can create the living entities, the bodies, living entities means the bodies, he can give the bodies for the living entities. By bringing forth the different varieties of the species. #### Kumaras, Vaikuntha, Doorkeepers, Srila Prabhupada
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/EKiUi9ClDW0?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta Purpa."
**Summary:** The speaker reads the translation and purport of S.B. 3.15.30, focusing on the Kumaras' appearance, their age, and the doorkeepers' actions.

Translation: The four boy sages, who had nothing to cover their bodies but the atmosphere, looked only five years old, even though they were the oldest of all living creatures and had realized the truth of the self. But when the porters, who happened to possess a disposition quite unpalatable to the Lord, saw the sages, they blocked their way with their staffs, despising their glories, although the sages did not deserve such treatment at their hands. Purport by Srila Prabhupada: The four sages were the first born sons of Brahma; therefore, all other living entities, including Lord Shiva, are born later and are therefore younger than the four Kumaras. Although they looked like five-year-old boys and traveled naked, the Kumaras were older than all other living creatures and had realized the truth of the self, such that they could not remain negligible and thus became known as the king of all the world. However, the sages were not to be forbidden to enter the kingdom of Vaikuntha, but by chance the doorman objected to their entrance. This is not fitting. The Lord is always anxious to serve sages like the Kumaras, but in spite of knowing this fact, the doorman astonishingly and outrageously prohibited them from entering. Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta Purport.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/KHe8E-ZPO-4?t=136
**Verse References:** BG 5.29

**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers

**Summary:** The speaker highlights Krishna as the best friend and explains the relationship between desire and anger, introducing the concept of anger as the younger brother of desire.

The four Kumaras came to see the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Narayana. The word suhrtama, best of all friends, is important. As Lord Krishna states in the Bhagavad Gita, he is the best friend of all living entities, suhrdam sarva bhutanam. No one can be a greater well-wishing friend to any living entity than the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He is so kindly disposed towards everyone, that in spite of our completely forgetting our relationship with the Supreme Lord, he comes himself, sometimes personally as Lord Krishna appeared on this earth, and sometimes as his devotee, as did Lord Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, and sometimes he sends his bona fide devotees to reclaim all the fallen souls. Therefore, he is the greatest well-wisher. He is the best well-wishing friend of everyone, and the Kumaras wanted to see him. The doorkeepers should have known that the four sages had no other business, and therefore to restrict them from entering the palace was not apt. In this verse, it is figuratively stated that the younger brother of desire suddenly appeared in person when the sages were forbidden to see their most beloved personality of Godhead. The younger brother of desire is anger.

#### anger, liberation, Krishna consciousness, sense gratification
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/KHe8E-ZPO-4?t=231
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The difference between the anger of an ordinary person and that of a liberated person is that an ordinary person becomes angry because his sense desires are not being fulfilled, whereas a liberated person like the Kumaras becomes angry when restricted in the discharge of duties for serving the Supreme Personality of Godhead."
**Summary:** The speaker differentiates between anger in the conditioned and liberated states, emphasizing that liberated individuals become angry when service to Krishna is obstructed, not for personal gratification.

If once desire is not fulfilled, the younger brother anger follows. Here we can mark that even great saintly persons like the Kumaras were also angry, but they were not angry for their personal interests. They were angry because they were forbidden to enter the palace to see the personality of Godhead. Therefore, the theory that in the perfectional stage one should not have anger is not supported in this verse. Anger will continue even in the liberated stage. These four mendicant brothers, the Kumaras, were considered liberated persons, but still they were angry because they were restricted in their service to the Lord. The difference between the anger of an ordinary person and that of a liberated person is that an ordinary person becomes angry because his sense desires are not being fulfilled, whereas a liberated person like the Kumaras becomes angry when restricted in the discharge of duties for serving the Supreme Personality of Godhead. In the previous verse, it has been clearly mentioned that the Kumaras were liberated persons. Vidhita Atma Tattva means one who understands the truth of self-realization. One who does not understand the truth of self-realization is called ignorant. But one who understands the self, the super-self, their interrelation and activities in self-realization is called Vidhita Atma Tattva. Although the Kumaras were already liberated persons, they nevertheless became angry. This point is very important. Becoming liberated does not necessitate losing one's sensual activities. Sense activities continue even in the liberated stage. The difference is, however, that sense activities in liberation are accepted only in connection with Krishna Consciousness, whereas sense activities in the conditioned stage are enacted for personal sense gratification.

**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/_8Hx3BFK-YU?t=45

**Key Quote:** "A Kshatriya is courageous in battle. He never retreats from a battle."
**Summary:** The lecture discusses Krishna's quality of accepting responsibility, particularly his display of chivalry as a Kshatriya, referencing the qualities of a Kshatriya as described in the Bhagavad Gita.

In this session we will be discussing the same verses which we were discussing in the previous few sessions. Four sessions we have already completed, discussing these set of verses, 25 to 30 of the 16th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. These are the verses describing the 40 transcendental qualities that are to be found in the Supreme Lord, which Mother Earth is describing to Dharma. So among the qualities of Krishna, one of the qualities described is his responsibility, quality of accepting responsibility. So even in his transcendental pastimes, his different role in his transcendental pastimes, he accepts responsibility and carries out his responsibility very, very wonderfully. So Sri Ramaprabha is describing when he is playing the part of a Kshatriya as the son of Maharaj Vasudeva, he displayed that Kshatriya quality of being chivalrous. So Sri Ramaprabha says, a Kshatriya king has to secure a wife by fighting or kidnapping a princess, sometimes. This sort of behavior for a Kshatriya is praiseworthy in the sense that a Kshatriya must show his power of chivalry to his would-be wife, so that the daughter of a Kshatriya is not taken away from him. The daughter of a Kshatriya can see the valor of her would-be husband. A Kshatriya princess, she wants demonstration before she marries another Kshatriya king. She wants to see his power of chivalry, his bravery. Not that he is dressed up and he is having some wealth, but actually in his heart he is not having that courage to fight. Kshatriya means he should have the courage to fight to the extent that if required he is willing to give up his life, but he will not give up the fight. Yuddhecha api apalayanam. This is described in the Bhagavad Gita by Krishna in the 18th chapter, in the 43rd verse, describing the qualities of a Kshatriya. A Kshatriya is courageous in battle. He never retreats from a battle.

#### chivalry, pastimes of Rama, pastimes of Krishna, marriage
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/_8Hx3BFK-YU?t=226

**Summary:** The segment narrates instances from the pastimes of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna where they displayed chivalry and courage to secure their wives, highlighting Rama breaking the bow of Lord Shiva and Krishna rescuing Rukmini.

So, in displaying his courage in battle, Krishna, in order to marry some princess, he actually displayed his courage by actually fighting in some cases. So Srila Prabhupada says even the personality of Godhead Sri Rama displayed such a chivalry, a spirit of chivalry during his marriage. He broke the strongest bow called Haradhanus and achieved the hand of Sita Devi, the mother of all opulence. Lord Rama is a supreme lord, but he appeared as the son of a Kshatriya, as Dasharatha's son. And when Vishwamitra took Lord Ramachandra, he was a small boy, a young prince. Vishwamitra took him to protect his sacrificial arena. Dasharatha initially was hesitant, but when Vishwamitra explained to Dasharatha, your son is no ordinary person. He is a supreme lord incarnated as your son. So don't have any doubts whether your son can give protection to my sacrificial arena. Anyway, Dasharatha agreed and finally sent Rama and Lakshmana. So Rama and Lakshmana were young princes, but they fought against 14,000 rakshasa associates of Ravana who were disturbing the sacrificial arena of Vishwamitra Rishi and other saintly persons. So Rama killed all of them and delivered all the 14,000 rakshasa. So that's only possible for the Supreme Personality of Karthik. But he displayed that, that chivalry. And when Sita Swayamvara, Janaka had declared that whichever king wants to marry my daughter, beautiful daughter, the mother of all opulence, Sita Devi, Lakshmiji, then they have to actually break one very, very, very heavy bow, Haradhanu, bow of Lord Shiva. Three hundred men had to carry it to bring it to the place where the competition was to take place. And single-handedly of course Lord Rama lifted it. Not only lifted it as a heavy bow, but he also broke that strongest bow easily, very effortlessly he broke it. So he actually demonstrated his strength as a powerful Kshatriya. Lord Krishna also he had to fight like a chivalrous Kshatriya to secure a wife. Just like Rukmini, it was scheduled, Rukmini was scheduled to marry someone else, Shishupala, against her wish and against her father's wish also, her elder brother decided to marry Rukmini to Shishupala. And Rukmini wanted to marry Krishna because she is a devotee of Krishna. So she sent a secret letter to Krishna, kindly rescue me. Krishna came to rescue and he had to fight against the army of Shishupala, army of Shishupala, and he fought very bravely and kidnapped Rukmini and brought her safely to Dwaraka.

**Summary:** The lecture delves into the quality of knowledge, breaking it down into five subheadings: intelligence, gratefulness, understanding circumstances, perfect knowledge, and self-knowledge, emphasizing the importance of gratitude and the Lord's reciprocation of devotional service.

Then there is one more quality called knowledge. The 14th quality called knowledge. It can be analyzed under five subheadings. So the first one is intelligence. Second one, second subheading of knowledge is gratefulness. Third one is power of understanding the circumstantial environments of place, object and time. And fourth one is perfect knowledge of everything in this world. And the fifth one, the last one, under the five subheadings. The fifth one is knowledge of the self is the most confidential knowledge. We all look like we are some material body, product of matter, and we think that way also. I am this body. But actually we are not a body. We are not material in nature. We are spiritual. We are spirit soul. So this knowledge of the self, the real I, a spirit soul, this knowledge is the most confidential one. It is called Brahmavidya, Atmavidya, Adhyatmavidya. Different names are same. Knowledge of the self. So these five subheadings, Prabhupada explains briefly regarding gratitude. Prabhupada says, Only fools are ungrateful to their benefactors. What does it mean? If I take some benefit from somebody, I should be grateful to that person who is offering me some benefit. That's the least I can do after receiving some benediction. I should at least be grateful to that person. So the Supreme Lord's position is that he does not require any benefit from anyone, because he is completely full in himself. Atma Rama is self-satisfied, because he is the owner of every resource. He is the supreme proprietor of everything and everyone. So what is the need for him? There is no need for him of anything. So there is no question of the Lord being in want. But still when his pure devotees render him service, he feels benefited by their pure devotional service, and therefore he feels grateful to his devotees for their unsophisticated, unconditional service, and tries to reciprocate that service of the devotees by himself

So, he tried to kill Parikshit in the womb of his mother. But Parikshit was saved by Krishna when this danger was there. So, Parikshit knew that he was saved by the Supreme Lord Narayana or Lord Krishna when he was in the womb of his mother. And similarly, if he were to be killed by a snake bite, it would also take place by the will of the Lord. So, the devotee never goes against the will of the Lord. Anything sent by God is a blessing for the devotee.

#### Caitanya Mahaprabhu, spiritual master, qualification
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/UT9iNBB49kc?t=384

**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes that Caitanya Mahaprabhu strictly followed the principle that anyone conversant with the science of Krishna can be accepted as an acarya or guru, regardless of their birth or social status.

Caitanya Mahāprabhu strictly followed this principle of the Bhagavatam. Just like Suta Goswami became qualified, and he became cleansed of all disqualifications simply by associating with pure devotees. Same thing, Caitanya Mahāprabhu himself gave association and he elevated those who were disqualified by birth or action to the status of devotional service. And when they become situated on this platform of pure devotional service, they become authorities. They attain the position of ācāryas, those who can teach others by their own example. They are perfect in knowledge and realization. So, Caitanya Mahāprabhu clearly stated, any man, whatever he may be, whether a brāhmaṇa or a śūdra, by birth, or a householder or a mendicant in the order of society, if he is conversant with the science of Kṛṣṇa, he can be accepted as an ācārya or guru, a spiritual master. The exact verse is, kibha vipra kibha nyāsi śūdra kenanāya yehi kṛṣṇa tattvaveta sei guru hoya. This is Caitanya Mahāprabhu's statement. This means, irrespective of the position, either in the varṇa or the āśrama, varṇa positions, the highest is brāhmaṇa, the lowest is śūdra. So, Caitanya Mahāprabhu says it doesn't matter what the varṇa position is of a person. Neither the āśrama position, whether one is householder or mendicant in the order of society, that means whether one is grāṣṭa or sannyāsi, it doesn't matter. If he is conversant with the science of Kṛṣṇa, yehi kṛṣṇa tattvaveta, kṛṣṇa tattva, in truth he knows what is Kṛṣṇa, then he can be accepted as ācārya or guru, or a spiritual master.

The rigidity of the so-called caste system in Hindu society became prominent within only one hundred years or so, when the number of dvija bandhus or disqualified men in the families of higher caste increased. Prabhupāda is clearly pointing out in the last hundred years or so, that is, if you count from now, when Prabhupāda is writing the purport, he says last hundred years this has become so, vitiated caste system, Hindu caste system. But that was not the case before. So, how did this happen in the last hundred years or hundred and fifty years? Because the number of disqualified people taking birth in higher caste increased. And then, such disqualified people, they don't have qualification, they claim, I am a brāhmaṇa by birth. But without qualification, what is the use of such birth? It is useless. It is no good. So, therefore, Prabhupāda explains that birth is not important, but the qualification of the person after taking birth, whatever be the family, if they acquire the qualifications by proper hearing, then they are washed off all the contamination of the lower birth. In this session we will discuss from the 21st verse of the 18th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: Athapiyatpada Nakhaava Srishtam Jagadvirincho Pahruta Arganambhaha Sesham Punati Anyatamau Mukundarth Konamaloke Bhagavadpadarthaha. The meaning of this verse is, who can be worthy of the name of the Supreme Lord but the personality of God as Sri Krishna? Brahmaji collected the water emanating from the nails of his feet in order to award it to Lord Shiva as a worshipful welcome. This very water, the Ganges, is purifying the whole universe including Lord Shiva. This is yet another word spoken by Suta Goswami to assert that Krishna is the supreme personality recorded because in the Shruti literature, in the original Vedas, there is so much description of the supreme absolute truth in impersonal feature, especially the Upanishads, that people think according to the Shrutis the absolute truth is impersonal only, but that is completely wrong. The absolute truth is impersonal, localized, and personal, and the person is the ultimate source of even the localized feature and the impersonal feature.

God. So, Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, the word Ajita is significant here. The personality of God, Shri Krishna, is known as Ajita, or unconquerable, and he... Elsewhere in the Bhagavatam, it is described that the Supreme Lord appeared as Ajita when the churning of the milk ocean was going on, it was about to begin, and in order to favor the Devatas who wanted to produce nectar by churning the milk ocean, he assumed the form of a tortoise, Kurma Rupa or Kurma Avatara, the tortoise incarnation. So Prabhupada points out here, "Herein Shrunge, a qualified son of a great brahmana, attained the required brahmanical power both by birth and by training, but he was lacking in culture because he was an inexperienced boy." Even though he was powerful, he was not sufficiently experienced how to utilize the power that he had acquired. By the influence of Kali, the son of a brahmana became puffed up with brahmanical power and thus wrongly compared Maharaj Pariksit to crows and watchdogs. This comparison is completely inappropriate just because this boy, inexperienced boy, was very proud of his brahmanical power. The king is certainly the watchdog of the state in the sense that he keeps vigilant eyes over the border of the state for its protection and defense. But to address him as a watchdog is a sign of a less cultured boy. He is supposed to protect, he is supposed to govern the country or the state or the province, but he cannot be treated like a low-class servant the way Sringi is thinking that the king has become an upstart. Thus the downfall of the brahmanical powers began as they gave importance to birthright without culture. If a brahmana is uncultured then he may wrongly claim to be a brahmana simply by birthright. "I am born in a brahmana family therefore I should be treated as a brahmana." But what about your culture? What about your education? What about your training? What about your qualification? What about your experience? All these are important factors. The downfall of the brahmana caste began in the age of Kali. According to scriptures, 5000 years back Kali Yuga began and that is when unqualified people started claiming this because of birthright that we are brahmanas, we should be respected as brahmanas by all the others. Whereas the others are observing these brahmanas are not qualified and they are wrongly claiming to be brahmanas. So they started losing respect and that is when everything became topsy-turvy. Since brahmanas are the heads of the social order all other orders of society also began to deteriorate.

#### humility, surrender, detachment, mercy of the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/XYR_B2uQVU8?t=54
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "A devotee is fully surrendered to Krishna, and his life is in Krishna's hands. So he considers anything that happens, good or bad in his life, materially good or bad, to be the mercy of the Supreme Lord."
**Summary:** HH Stoka Krishna Swami explains Pariksit Maharaj's humble acceptance of the brahmana's curse as the Lord's mercy, highlighting the devotee's surrender and detachment from material attachments.

In this session we will be discussing two verses, the fourteenth and the fifteenth verses of the nineteenth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. So the fourteenth verse is as follows: तस्यैवमे अगस्य परावरेशो व्यासक्त चित्तस्य ग्रहेश्व भीक्षनं निर्वेदमूलो विजशापरूपो यत्रप्रसक्तो भयमाशुधत्ते. The meaning of this fourteenth verse is: The Supreme Personality of Godhead, the controller of both the transcendental and mundane worlds, has graciously overtaken me in the form of a Brahmana's curse. Due to my being too much attached to family life, the Lord, in order to save me, has appeared before me in such a way that only out of fear I will detach myself from the world. So what is Pariksit telling? That he considers himself to be an attached householder. He is taking a humble position as a pure devotee. Pure devotees are always very, very humble. Even though they are the most advanced transcendentalists, they don't consider themselves as very advanced. So they are careful not to become proud, not to be arrogant, not to offend others. Pariksit is taking, especially in front of the saintly persons who have all assembled there, a very humble position: that I am too much attached to family life. I was living in a comfortable palace. I was surrounded by so much wealth, power, comforts. So in order to make me detached from this world, the Supreme Lord has appeared before me in the form of a brahmana's curse to die within seven days. So this is the nature of a devotee. A devotee is fully surrendered, a pure devotee especially, is fully surrendered to Krishna, and his life is in Krishna's hands. So he considers anything that happens, good or bad in his life, materially good or bad, to be the mercy of the Supreme Lord. This is explained in the Bhagavatam, 10th canto, 14th chapter, in the prayers of Lord Brahma to Krishna: Tattenu Kampam Susamiksha Mano Bhunjana Evatmakrita Vipakam. My dear Lord, it is only your mercy that I am facing some material difficulties or some material miseries because actually I deserve to suffer much, much, much, much more due to my own past misdeeds. But you are so kind to your devotee that you have reduced that suffering that I have to undergo to the minimum as a token to encourage me in my devotional service, and that is only because of your causeless mercy upon me. So this is the attitude of a devotee when the devotee faces some difficulty or some calamity or some danger or some misery. He never blames the Lord, but rather he considers that difficulty to be the Lord's mercy upon him, and as a result of that, the devotee becomes detached from everything material, becomes completely detached.

So therefore, yuktatamomata. So I'll stop here. Thank you very much.

Receiving respect from all, Shukadeva Goswami took his exalted seat. It's in the purport Srila Prabhupada explains very nicely. On Shukadeva Goswami's arrival at the meeting, everyone except Srila Vyasadeva, Narada and a few others stood up. See, it was described, great sages, because of physiognomy, they could recognize Shukadeva Goswami, even though he is not properly dressed by his external bodily features, so they stood up out of respect. But not Vyasadeva Narada. Why? Because Vyasadeva is Shukadeva Goswami's own spiritual master. Narada is the spiritual master of the spiritual master. Narada is Vyasadeva's spiritual master. So Vyasadeva and Narada did not stand up, and few others who were great personalities, they did not stand up. But everybody else stood up out of respect for Shukadeva Goswami. Now, what about Maharaj Pariksit? It is described here. Maharaj Pariksit was very glad to receive a great devotee of the Lord, and he bowed down before Shukadeva Goswami with all the limbs of his body. Dandavat, dandavat pranama, or sastanga pranama, different ways this is said. So here it is described that he bowed down with all his limbs of his body. Saparyam shirasam ajaharao. With all the limbs of his body, he bowed down completely to Shukadeva Goswami. Shukadeva Goswami also exchanged the greetings and reception by embrace, shaking of hands, nodding and bowing down, especially before his father and Narada Muni. Shukadeva Goswami knew how to exchange greetings, depending on the different person's position or achievements. So with some equals, he was shaking hands. With juniors, he was embracing them. And acknowledging some people's greetings by nodding his head. And especially to his father Vyasadeva and Narada Muni, he bowed down himself, because he is a junior. Thus, Shukadeva Goswami was offered the presidential seat at the meeting, because he was the greatest, realized, advanced, spiritually advanced personality of his time, recognized by all other great persons. So he was offered the seat of the president of the assembly, the chief person in that assembly of Parikshit Maharaj. When he was so received by the kings and sages, the street boys and less intelligent women who were following him were struck with wonder and fear. So they retired from their frivolous activities. Everything was full of gravity and calm. You see how the whole atmosphere changed completely after the arrival of Shukadeva Goswami.

Krishna is playing that role in his pastimes, in his Leela, Dwaraka, the king of Dwaraka. So, Krishna is telling, a human being who identifies this body, this material body, made up of three elements, with the self, Yesya Atma Buddhi, who am I? Actually, most people think, I am this body, this body, this body is who I am, is myself. But, Shastra says, no, scripture says, no, Bhagavad Gita says, no, this body is not you, you are not the body, you are spirit, soul. So, what if a person, in ignorance, mistaken identity, that I am this body, and what is this body made of? So, somebody who thinks this bag is, this bag is, this bag is, this bag is, this bag is, a point, this bag is called the physical body, which consists of three elements, somebody thinks this has the self, and further, Swadhi, Kalatra, Deishu, who considers the byproducts of the body to be his Kingsman, that is, my wife, my children, they are all mine, who considers his land of birth, they give a lot of importance. I have taken birth, let us say, in Mysore. So Mysore is a very, very, very important place for me. And he thinks, such a person, a materialistic person, an ignorant person, a foolish person, a person under the influence of the illusory energy, thinks that one should go to a place of pilgrimage simply to take a bath, so that if all my sins are washed away, I don't have to suffer any sinful reaction. I can enjoy without any hindrance. If this attitude a person has, such a person is considered Saha eva Goh Kharaha. He is no better than an animal, like an ass or a cow. Kharaha means ass, and Goh means cow. That means he is not a human being with developed intelligence.

So, it is also true that great saintly persons who are completely aloof from worldly enjoyers, they do not bother to meet or contact or approach any of the materialistic persons or people in royal position, big big kings, big big wealthy merchants, people in big positions in material estimation, they never approach. So, Srila Prabhupada next gives an example. Maharaja Pratap Rudra was a follower of Lord Chaitanya. He was the king of Orissa. But when Maharaja Pratap Rudra wanted to see the Lord, see Lord Chaitanya, Lord Chaitanya refused to see him because he was a king. So, Pratap Rudra, even though he was a king, he was a saintly king. So, he was seeking an interview with Chaitanya Mahaprabhu just to get blessings, just to get some instructions, personal instructions, when Chaitanya Mahaprabhu was staying in Puri. So, Pratap Rudra, who would not give any appointment, would not agree to meet Pratap Rudra Maharaj, why? Why would Chaitanya refuse? Prabhupada says, for a devotee who desires to go back to Godhead, two things are strictly prohibited, worldly enjoyers and women. Now, this is based on a verse that is there in the Chaitanya Charitamrita. That verse says, The meaning of this verse is, It is more abominable than drinking poison willingly. So, as Prabhupada says in this purport, two things are strictly forbidden for a serious transcendentalist who is practicing spiritual life in order to get out of material existence entirely and go back to Godhead. So, this verse says, this is a verse quoted by, spoken by Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. When Chaitanya Mahaprabhu was requested by one of his associates, Sarvam Bhattacharya, that please give an appointment for Maharaj Pratap Rudra who wants to come and see you, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu said, no, I cannot give an appointment. He wants to cross over the ocean of material existence and go back to Godhead. For such a person, Sandarshanam, just seeing. Not even mixing or interacting. Not even interacting very closely. No, just seeing. Sandarshanam. Two categories of people. Vishayinam, Yoshitam. Vishayinam means those who are engaged in materialistic activities. Vishayinam. Sense enjoyers in this world. And, Yoshitam means women. Women here refers to a member of the opposite gender. Who is very much interested in enjoying. For a woman, it is man. Yoshit is man. For a man, a Yoshit is woman. Who is interested in enjoying. Such a Darshan, just a Sandarshanam, just seeing, is very, very dangerous. How dangerous? More dangerous than drinking poison willingly. Than knowingly drinking poison. That means, it is very very dangerous. It is a big big big obstacle for spiritual advancement.
